awd_abstract_narration:
Developing and maintaining infrastructure is important for enabling future research on disappearing languages. This award supports the modernization and enhancement of language infrastructure in one of the oldest and most important repositories of materials held in the country: the indigenous language collections held at the University of Chicago. The collections, some extending back a century, are currently dispersed across different units in the university, have been catalogued differently, and are difficult to access. To unlock the full scientific and social value of these collections, they need to be physically consolidated, uniformly catalogued, and readily accessible both to researchers and the public. The proposed enhancements will facilitate scientific and historical research on languages, support heritage-language maintenance and education efforts, and contribute to general public understanding of human cultural and linguistic diversity. 

The University of Chicago’s indigenous language collections include audio recordings in the Digital Media Archives, language texts in the Archive of Indigenous Literatures, unpublished linguistic and ethnographic manuscripts in the Manuscripts on Cultural Anthropology, and indigenous language instructional materials. These collections will be consolidated in the main library of the university, where the staff have significant experience in long-term digital preservation. This project integrates, standardizes, and enhances the heterogeneous metadata used in the collections. Basic library cataloguing standards will be uniformly employed and enhanced metadata on language, location, and content type will be provided. Links will connect related items across collections and one unified web portal for the consolidated collections will be developed. The portal will include efficient browsing and finding tools and provides guidance on how to navigate the site both for academic researchers and heritage speaker communities. For materials not in the public domain, the site will explain the procedures for obtaining access.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project enhanced infrastructure for the University of Chicago?s archival collections of materials documenting the indigenous languages of Mesoamerican. This was done to ensure that they remain an important and useful repository both for scholars and the public, including heritage communities. 

Chicago?s Mesoamerican collections are substantial, containing thousands of items. They are historically deep, dating back to the 1930s, containing some of the earliest recorded materials available on languages of this region. And they are broad in scope, including recorded, printed, manuscript, and other materials on scores of languages, some extinct or endangered, others revitalizing or still flourishing. However, before commencement of this project, the collections lacked effective infrastructure. They were institutionally dispersed among three different units of the University, some not prepared to provide long term care. They were catalogued using different and often outdated systems. And they were individually and collectively difficult to discover and access. The current project addressed these concerns in order to assure the sustainability, discoverability, and accessibility of the collections.

To insure sustainability, the project consolidated four dispersed collections under the institutional umbrella of the University's Library, the unit most appropriate for long term preservation. These collections included (1) over 2000 recorded materials held in the Digital Media Archives, administered by the Humanities Division; (2) over 1000 printed works in indigenous languages held in the Chicago Archive of Indigenous Literatures of Latin America, administered by the Center for Latin American Studies; (3) hundreds of unpublished materials containing linguistic and ethnographic field materials on over 100 Mesoamerican languages held in the Microfilm Collection of Manuscripts on Cultural Anthropology and in other manuscript collections held by the Library; and (4) instructional materials held in the Digital Maya Collection, administered by the Humanities Division, with courses that have come to represent both reference and teaching standards. Together they now form the University of Chicago Mesoamerican Language Collections (MLC). 

To increase discoverability of materials in the MLC, the project integrated, standardized, and enhanced the cataloguing system, or metadata scheme, used for the collections. Basic modern library cataloguing standards have been uniformly employed. Enhanced metadata has been produced for language, location, and content type so as to address the most salient needs of researchers working on these languages. In particular, since languages and communities often have a range of names that they can take, the metadata scheme uses what is called linked data to allow various alternative names for a language to each lead to the relevant set of items. Finally, related items contained in the separate collections (e.g., recordings, transcripts, related fieldnotes, etc.) are now connected by matching metadata and/or by direct cross references. 

To enhance accessibility, the project developed a unified web portal for the consolidated collections at https://mlc.lib.uchicago.edu. The individual collections, beginning first with the recorded materials, are now being incorporated into this unified site. The portal itself provides browsing and finding tools based on the integrated, standardized, and enhanced cataloguing metadata scheme described above so items can be quickly and accurately located. The portal includes both English and Spanish interfaces to enhance access. It will also provide guidance on how to navigate the site effectively to meet the needs of both academic researchers and heritage speaker communities. And for the benefit of those building or managing other, similar archives, the completed site will provide full documentation of the metadata systems used. Finally, for access to the materials themselves, some will be freely downloadable whereas others, for example, those under copyright or subject to various depositor restrictions) will require registering a formal request. 

Collectively, these changes assure that the scientific value of the collections will be sustained for the long-term. The research value of the existing collections has been enhanced by the application of both standard and enriched metadata structures that then support improved browsing and finding functionality on the website and clear routes for access to the materials. Further, it will now be possible for the MLC to accept new deposits of language materials in a coherent way, providing both a secure and accessible home for many more such materials. Finally, the collaboration between language researchers and metadata specialists has also produced several archiving innovations that may prove useful to others building language collections of this type both in the U.S. and in the Mesoamerican region. 

The project ultimately contributes to the broader social good of preserving information about linguistic and cultural diversity. The depth and scope of the materials should prove relevant not only to those studying linguistics and anthropology, but also for historians of these fields and of indigenous language movements. The accessible online interface should facilitate heritage speaker communities discovering and accessing materials not only for those interested in historical materials for language preservation and revitalization but also those interested in accessing contemporary materials relevant to their own recording and publishing traditions.
